result.execSummary:
The defendant Patrick T Brah was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Repeater], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Huber with standard release conditions if revoked.  Sentence credit for 20 days were granted.

miscConds.notes: Submit to an AODA assessment, follow through with any treatment recommended.  No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety. No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription. Any valid prescriptions drugs must be taken in the manner they are prescribed.  Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent.  Sign Medical Release for Agent.
Defendant is not to possess any weapons/firearms.

No violent contact with Julie Brah, Dustin Brah or CJB (DOB 1/21/2013).
Operate a Motor Vehicle with a Valid Driver's License.
  Defendant to provide DNA sample, if not yet provided,   immediately if in custody otherwise within (3) business days at the Waukesha County Sheriff Department.
  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

Costs/DNA Surcharge waived.
Bail to be applied to 16CF440.

Defendant was highly intoxicated and that was why he was arrested yesterday.  New charge will be charged today.  Court schedules these cases for a hearing.
